reviewText:
A few years ago I went searching for a game like Tyrian, my favorite space shooter from the late 90s. I didn’t find anything. There were tons of space shooters, sure, but Tyrian had a great customization system, and over a decade later I couldn’t find a game that compared, much less improved on it. Turns out Psycho Starship Rampage is the game I was looking for.

PSR is a customization-heavy rogue-like game built on the skeleton of a standard space shooter. Gameplay is divided into two parts. Stages are pretty standard shooter levels with waves of enemies, terrain hazards, and a final boss. But, after each one, you go into “hyperspace” where you can use parts picked up in the prior level to customize almost every aspect of your ship. Thus the game cycles between design and battle until your eventual demise.

What makes PSR special is the ship customization. This isn’t merely a matter of selecting weapons or some such—PSR gives you the ability to design a ship from the ground up. You build the body of your ship of basic geometric blocks and give it functionality by installing devices on them. You decide the number, location, and type of engines, power generators, batteries, repair units, and weapons. You have control over the precise angle of guns and, in a very clever feature, over key bindings of individual components, meaning that you can map weapons systems to keys in whatever combinations you like. Your customization is only limited by what you pick up in the levels: technologies are rolled like RPG weapons, meaning that even two lvl 1 blaster patterns won’t be identical. Upgrades must be paid for with scrap salvaged from your exploded foes.

This system is the game’s strongest feature. Your design decisions are significant, noticeably altering how your ship plays. The interface is clear and easily learned. And there is opportunity to test your customizations out before embarking on another level—a smart feature I wouldn’t have known to ask for. Designing ships is what I most enjoyed about this game.

The actual shooter is well-executed, but unremarkable and a bit plain. Enemies are rather abstract looking and all come in the same color. The only other element of a stage is random space debris such as meteors. Backgrounds are nice looking but simple. One noteworthy feature of play is the variety of ways to fight. In addition to projectile weapons, you can install impact weapons (energy spikes) or tractor beams which allow you to bludgeon enemies with debris. (This is the only game I’ve played in this genre where terrain obstacles hurt opponents as much as you.) My only real complaint with play is that in some stages small debris, background elements, and scrap look enough alike that, in the thick of things, it can be hard to tell which is which.

There is a story mode which honestly I’ve yet to thoroughly explore. (It was not implemented yet for the beta period where most of my play took place.) It’s mechanics are largely the same as those described above, though. Still, I can say that the game’s quirky, somewhat morbid humor, present in both modes, actually succeeds in being good for a laugh. Also, parts of the game’s sound track are quite catchy.

On the other hand I was a bit bothered by the progression mechanic. In typical rogue-like fashion technologies, including fairly essential ones, are to be unlocked with play. Now, right up-front I should say that I dislike grinding. Having to play many games at a handicap while you unlock everything is my least favorite feature of current rogue-likes. In the beta, this frustration was compounded by extreme difficulty. The most recent release seems to have mostly fixed the problem; there still is the need to run survival mode many times to unlock everything though. Also, the devs are listening, and this makes me hopeful that whatever tweaks are still needed will take place.

At this point, the only really major complaint I have is that the game involves insufficient documentation. I had to figure many things out by trial and error, and in a few very opaque cases I had to consult the devs for answers.

I really like the core of this game. Building your own ship and blowing things up with it is good fun. There is still room for some polishing and tweaking, but this is a solid implementation of an interesting concept. I’ve been looking for a game like Pscyho Starship Rampage.

[Disclaimer: I received a review copy of this game from the developers.]

reviewText:
A bullethell-esque game with ARPG-esque loot.

It's a bit short but it's a hell of a lot of fun.  I buy a lot of cheapish games on steam and rarely sink more than an hour into any of them... I played this one through to completion (only took me 5 hours, but they were a very fun 5 hours).  I haven't tried survival mode yet but if that's done right I'll definitely sink more into that.

From reading the negative review (someone thinking it's too hard/unfair) it seems that it could take some significantly more than 5 hours to play, but to call any of it unfair is nonsense.  I had a few points where I struggled to beat areas but that's because I'd try to tackle the hardest available levels (relative to your current power) most of the time.  And after all of that later in the game I figured out a significantly better way to change up my ship that made me much more powerful.  Half the game is how you outfit your ship and that part is done well.  The menu for it is a little clunky/a bit of a learning curve to navigate through it fluidly but after the slight learning curve it works great.

It's well worth the price.  This is only the second game I've bothered to review on steam.

Oh.. and the negative review about controls not being customizable is bull.  The customization is simply done part by part in the ship editor (and not some sort of global menu).  A global menu for controls would be too limiting.

reviewText:
Get it if you
- like arcade shooter games
- want to customize your spaceship, making extreme tactics valid (ramming, regenerating ship anyone?)
- don't mind random spikes in difficulty
- rooted for HAL in Space Odyssey, Skynet in the Terminator, and the Borg in Star Trek

Don't get if you want
- a lot of different enemy types
- more realistic or artsy graphics
- a good storyline with meaningful choices
- true space physics

reviewText:
With Psycho Starship Rampage (PSR for short), you always come back for more!
I remember when I was first showed the alpha version (long before Steam, that is), and it definitely has come a long way to become what it is now (in a good way).

I'll try to line up what I think is good and what I think is currently missing. Sorry for the long read, that's usually how I shape my reviews.


At the core
What makes PSR special among shooters is the great degree of freedom that is given to you for building your spaceship :
• Shape it however you like
• Fill it with anything you like, be it power generators, power storage, weapons, shields, armors, reactors, and so on. The balance between all of these is totally up to you. You can load a ♥♥♥♥-ton of weapons or only a few, focus on shielding the front, the back and/or the sides, and so on.
• Make yourself comfortable : Assign any keyboard key to any weapon (or group of weapons).
• Weapons can rotate at any time (assign keys to it).
• Equipment can be merged to keep the bonuses of each and turn it into a more powerful instrument (bad bonuses are merged too if I recall, so read the result before you confirm!).
• Construction menu takes a little while to get used to, but once you're get the hang of it, shaping your ship goes pretty fast.

The possibilities are infinite, and that's the cool part. Get Scrap (the game currency) on each level, and upgrade yourself 'till you're ridiculously badass... if you survive long enough.


Another thing that makes PSR really special is that you can play with up to 4 of your friends on the same ship! By that I mean, there is only one ship but you can distribute the movement and the weapon handling to anyone. So you can have, say, one person controlling the ship, and 3 people handling the weapons. The energy (used by weapons) is obviously shared so this leads to ridiculously fun situations. I remember one evening, we plugged 3 controllers and a keyboard and tried a 4-players session. That was messy, but we had a really good time! Just don't forget to put a ton of energy storage for those trigger-happy friends of yours...
Note that you only need one copy of the game to play with up to 4 friends on local co-op. This is great when you invite people at your home and want to have some fun, without connecting on 4 Steam accounts and all the stuff. Having a TV to plug the PC output is ideal imo.


The levels, the graphics, the soundtrack
Neon ships everywhere. It's actually a pretty clever idea, considering the fact that you need to make it look good with any possible shape. The assets look really nice, be it backgrounds or objects.
If you're a Steam Card collector, I don't think you'll be dissapointed (esp. if you like space stuff).
The soundtrack is great stuff as well, and while it'll definitely depend on the individual, I personally haven't got bored of the soundtrack so far.

No level is the same, as enemy spawns are random, and generated 'on the fly'.
At the end of each level, the boss is also randomly generated, and randomly equipped (weapons, that is). The boss becomes more powerful the longer you drag the fight (rage bar on top), so you have to balance the blows you take and the damage you make. Since the boss always changes, you need to adapt your strategy. Not a really big deal on the lower levels, but at higher levels, the bosses can surprise you... rather quickly.


I see a Rogue-like" tag up there

reviewText:
Combining shmup mechanics to rogue like level design and replay ability, with a hint of strategy when building your spaceship and experimenting, PSR is a very nice game!

I played almost 30 hours to the Steam Beta (and more before it was counted on Steam) still have thirst for more destruction, looting and upgrading!

The physic of the game may take a few games to get familliar with, but it also allows some fun tricks like using tractor beam on asteroid to use them a shield and weapon or stuff like that.

I think the game could benefit from some more tweaks and updates, and what better way to prove to the devs that we want more than recommading this game?

If you liked Kingdom Hearts Gummy Ship, rogue likes and/or shmups (thanksfully it doesn't require the same skill level as a manic shooter or even R-Type and Gradius!) : go for it!

reviewText:
While Psycho Starship Rampage has some flaws (that could be fixed), it does manage to be a fairly addicting roguelite experience. You essentially manage a modular space ship, which you can upgrade and expand through collecting scrap and various upgrades in levels. Upgrades are everything from ship speed, a multitude of weapons, energy capture, and repairing (I probably forgot one or two, as well). The levels are a top-down bullet-hell shooter. You can become overpowered, if you build your ship right - and get a little lucky. Ship management occurs between levels, and you progress along a path similiar to FTL where you jump through space.

Pros:
+Has an addicing 'one more run' feel that has you trying out different ship abilities
+Controller support is nice, although it can be clunky until you get used to it

Cons:
-Tutorial could be more in-depth
-Boss battles are embarrassingly bad - they need to 1)show a boss life meter, 2)be more than a larger enemy that just randomly moves around creating bullet hell, and 3)have some sort of personality or story point associated with it

This isn't perfect, but it certainly is a fun roguelite that I will be coming back to.

reviewText: Just beat the game and gotta say it's pretty awesome overall. I am a sucker for spaceship shooter games like Gradius 3 or Darius Twin and this did satisfy the itch. I will agree with some of the other reviews that some of the bosses do seem gimmicky, particularly the later laser bosses.  These ♥♥♥♥♥uckers give you no debris to hide behind and will just laser beam your ♥♥♥ to hell. I did find a cool item... once, the graviton missile. Sadly it seemed like in the 20 hours I played the flashy cool items were nowhere to be found. In fact the light-bulb collectable that seems to spawn the location of rare items disappeared after the 5th world or so. Not sure this is intended but when I beat the game I was close to 40 worlds visited which is a shame, because I would've really liked to have tried some of the other flashy weapons that are available. Great game if you like spaceship shooters, but could probably use some more polish in future patches. I give it 3 apples and a banana because I like spaceships and shooters, oh and the music was good too.

reviewText:
Here's a link to my review video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1MZn3e45Xs0

Hiya Gamers!

This is a review of Psycho Starship Rampage and I gave it a 3/5 because i'm very on the fence with this one. There are some aspects to this game that I really liked and others that I wasn't so fond of. You control the spaceship of a rogue A.I. that's trying to get back to Earth and destroy it. As you go across the galaxy a wave of enemies trails behind you like in FTL, if the wave catches up you lose. The gameplay is fun but I didn't like how rigid the enemies movement patterns were and started noticing a lot of similarities with the bosses at the end of each level. Some more movement patterns are added on as you go, but I didn't feel like there was a lot of difference. There is local co-op in the game, but be warned, you will not get extra ships. Instead, you and your friends can control different parts of the ship so be ready to ruin some friendships. I liked the graphics and the music was very outerspace-like and fit the game, but the most interesting part of the game is customizing your ship. So long as you have the scrap, you can make whatever you want. You have the ability to rotate your guns, bind different guns to different keys to conserve energy, and make guns shoot behind you.

Have Fun Gamers!

reviewText:
Psycho Starship Rampage is a game more than successful, unlike other similar games, the first levels are easy, and help you to boost the spacecraft.
But continuing becomes increasingly difficult and fun!
Graphic style simple but beautiful to see in action, catchy soundtrack, Gameplay nice solid!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WuvHYtsUoFc
(Below is the Italian full review)
Psycho Starship Rampage: Space Shooter + Rogue = Modifica la tua astronave!

In Psycho Starship Rampage si gioca con ina IA psicotica (intelligenza artificiale) di una nave da guerra persa nello spazio.. che cerca di tornare sulla terra.
Costruisci la tua astronave da zero, modificandola con varie armi.
Utilizza la tua creazione per distruggere l'ondate di alieni innocenti.. durante i numerosissimi livelli!
Conquista le loro carcasse, per estendere l'astronave rendendola sempre più potente!



Feature:
- Spara ondate di nemici in tanti livelli differenti a scorrimento orizzontale
- Molte armature e armi, che combinate possono rendere la navicella inarrestabile!
- Costruisci la tua macchina per uccidere
- Coop locale fino a 4 giocatori contemporaneamente
- Supporto al Gamepad e Carte Steam

Parere Personale:
Psycho Starship Rampage è un gioco più che riuscito, a differenza di altri giochi simili, i primi livelli sono facili, e ti aiutano a potenziare la navicella.
Ma continuando diventa sempre più difficile e divertente!
Stile grafico semplice ma bello da vedere in azione, soundtrack orecchiabile (e anche canticchiabile xD) Gameplay bello solido!
Insomma, lo consiglio senza alcun dubbio, soprattutto se cercate un Shoot 'em up fatto bene!

reviewText:
Ever dreamed of flying through space with the ability to customise your way and slaughter hordes of enemies in a rogue like setting? Well this game offers you this and much much more.

Psycho Starship Rampage is one of those fine gems you find within mountains of garbage. I have been playing this game since Feburary of this year (when it was at alpha version 0.9.1) and I'm still in awe at how far the game has come. From the jaw dropping visual designs to the adrenaline pumping music, this game will have you hook, line and sinker from the get go.

One of my all time favourite indie titles of 2015!

(PS: Don't believe that I have played it for that long? Find the video section on the forums and look for my 3 latest videos. From there you can find my channel and my old stuff)

reviewText:
Just finished the game and well, it kind of left me in a 50/50 feeling. I'll go to the good things first.

The ship customization is ingenious! It gives you all the freedom to create a ship that suits exactly your taste. This includes the shape, weapons, weapon directions, energytanks and so on. You can even assign different keybinds to different parts of the ship. It is easily the best part of the game.

Also destroying enemies feels great and satisfying. The music fits in the game quite well, though I only liked maybe one song. The songs resemble those annoying chiptune songs too much, but that's just my opinion, I don't count it as a flaw in the game. Graphics are also nice and flashy, kind of what you would expect from a space shooter.

While the ship customization is fantastic, along with some smaller things, the rest of the game isn't that tempting.

Starting with permadeath. Yeah you read it right, this game has permadeath, which affects many other things that ultimately lead to an unsatisfying gaming experience. Permadeath happens if the enemy wave reaches your position on the world (star) map. This means that you have about 6 lives, as every time you die, the wave moves closer to your position. This means no free exploring and collecting various items on the map, that you would maybe want.

You have to keep moving forward towards your goal. But you cannot move towards it too fast, since the levels are too hard compared to your level, so you always have to take the easy"
date: "medium" or at maximum the "hard" route. This means that you have to zigzag your way through the map. This then leads to a situation where you are only a couple of steps ahead of the permadeath wave at all times (so maybe 2 lives).\n\nThis then affects to your decisions regarding what weapons you'd like to equip. When you've found something that works
recommended: you cannot really differ from it
hoursPlayed: since if you try out a new setup and it doesn't work

reviewText: There are not enough games about psychotic AI starships on steam.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Psycho Starship Rampage is an interesting combination of a shmup and roguelike that I found fun for one playthrough, but lacks replay value. The game starts out feeling well balanced, with most enemies not feeling too bullet spongy, but still providing a good challenge. About halfway through the game, I discovered a beam weapons that made the game far easier. By the end of the game I'd slapped 5 beams onto my ship and was sweeping up and down the screen instanly wiping out anything as soon as it spawned, and occasionally wiping out the entire screen with a black hole for good measure. It was a lot of fun to be massacring the enemies that were previously such a challenge, but it made the last half of the game far too easy. Even the bosses would die in 5 to 10 seconds of sitting under my beams.

The game randomly generates waves of enemies and debris as you progress through the level, as well as a random boss at the end of each level. After a while I noticed the same waves repeating, and the levels started to feel very repetitive. The bosses are all very similar to one another as well - they all move in roughly the same pattern, with the guns being semi-randomized each time. I was disappointed when I got to the final mission, only to see that the last boss was just another of these generated bosses that died in 5 seconds rather than a climactic final battle. It's also worth noting that the game isn't really a roguelike if that's what you're looking for. The game features the same map from FTL with the fleet slowly advancing on you. When you die, you don't start over, the fleet only advances a little further and you start the level over again.

Despite these flaws, the game feels good to play. The controls are a little floaty, but otherwise solid, and binding different weapons to buttons of your choosing is a core feature of the game. The game's best feature is obviously the complete customization of the ship. You can make it take any shape you want to, and the controls for assembling the ship work well with a controller. Components like generators, guns, and shields can all be bought with the scrap you collect from dead enemies, and placed anywhere on the ship. Guns can even be pointed in any direction to shape your bullet patterns as you please. It's offers a huge amount of customization without being overwhelmingly complex like other games that have attempted to put in similar features.

Graphically the game looks good, though not amazing. The art style is unique, bright, and makes it easy to see where everything except small bullets are. The bright red enemies are easy to keep track of, but this also makes it nearly impossible to tell enemies apart from one another and prioritize targets accordingly - until you have beam cannons that is, and just annihilate everything on screen.

The loot uses Diablo style system with affixes and randomized stats, though most loot you find up until the endgame is useful. The UI for collecting loot is bad, however. As you go through the level you picking up loot boxes. At the end of the level, you get to choose from one of two items from each box. The problem is that the screen doesn't show you the stats for any of the items as you are choosing between the two, so you can't tell if either of the choices is an upgrade or not. You also can only see the current item in the list, not the rest of them. You might end up choosing a generator instead of a cannon, and hoping for another cannon to appear, only to find 2 more generators and no cannons - something you wouldn't have done if you were able to see all the choices rather than being forced to go through one by one.

Despite it's flaws, I found the game to be a lot of fun, and I'll probably go back for a second playthrough at some point. There are no difficulty settings, however, which restricts the replay value of the game once you've nailed down the boss patterns and more or less memorized all of the spawn waves. Whether the game is worth your time at it's current price depends on you, but if you find it on sale, I'd highly reccommend picking it up immediately, as I very much enjoyed the time I spent on it.

reviewText:
Boss fights are dumb, sometimes stupid hard. The only time I die is at a boss. And where is the HP bar of the boss? Would be nice to know how much damage I done to a boss before I die. Why can't we disable parts of the boss's ship when it gets hurt like your own? Everything before a boss fight is super easy.

You can't configure controls on your mouse, like to fire guns with mouse button 1.

The ship creation controls are not fluid, and hard to tell what you are doing because of the lack of feedback.

Campain needs difficulty settings. For me, I failed 3 campains and feel very frustrated.

I don't use the gun turn controls because I don't have a third hand. One hand is needed for the ship movement, and the other hand for the shooting of the guns and secondary weapons. Controller or mouse support would help with this.

Music in the background got old super fast.

Easy to screw yourself over testing a ship build and wasting a run.

reviewText: I'm trying to like this game but it's just too buggy.  First I was crashing every 5 mins because the controls and key binds between keyboard and xbox 360 controllers are faulty.  Now I can't edit my ship because the view panel on the top left is half way off the screen, so I can't see anything I'm doing.  Save yourself some money and avoid this title.  Should have never been released in a state like this.  What a mess..
voteText: 2 of 15 people (13%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
The control options are non-existant. For a shooting game, I would like to be able to choose which hand controls movement and which fires, and I found no options to do so.

Also, the menus in-game clearly seem to indicate that a controller is supported as it asked me to hit the left arrow button (select) to access the upgrade menu, but I could not move my ship using the controller.

The final nail on the coffin is that the game crashed on me twice in 15 minutes. Never have I had this happen with a game, and I have purchased about a hundred so far on Steam.

Truly one of the more disappointing purchases I have ever made on Steam, because the game looked very interesting. You may have a better experience, but I would suggest trying something else in the genre as this one lacks polish.

reviewText:
Yay, another 2D space game that allows you to build your ship module by module! (see Reassembly and BossConstructor if you like that as much as I do)

The ship building part is brilliant (editor is even pretty usable on controller!) and it's also a pretty decent and hard arcade shooter, but there are too few enemy types and patterns. I wish enemies were randomly generated (or at least modified) and used the same damage model as the player ship giving more replayability and fun.

One noteworthy thing is the strange local co-op - you have one ship and you can map individual modules to buttons of your choice so multiple players can control different aspects of the same ship. However, game's rouge-like nature and difficulty spikes makes it very difficult to advance to a big enough ship where larger crew would make sense. Actually, it would be amazing to have say 3 players, one piloting and two operating different weapon systems! An option to start with much more resources and/or a way to (re)strore player designs would be nice.

Overall a very interesting game I don't regret buying for the full price. Just be ready to die a lot ;)

reviewText:
This is the best £6.99 I've spent in a long time.

I'm really enjoying this game, customizing my ships, making it look how I want, be it a simple box or a badass shard of death, it's really fun.

You start off the game with a little ship, it can kill enemies, yeah, doesn't do it as effeciently as it will do later on when you upgrade your weapons *cough cough* Lasers, but you can put more guns on but needs to be balanced out with more Generators so you can quickly regenerate the energy for your weapons, and Capacitors so as to store more energy so you can fire longer before having to stop to let your energy recharge, more powerful weapons generally mean they use more energy, but not always, weapons, depending on their grade, will come with bonuses, like -15% Cost or -10% Energy Conservation, that sort of thing.

The levels themselves can be fairly easy but the bosses are tougher and can take quite a beating, dodge their fire and keep hosing them down with either Bullets, Lasers, Rockets, Plasma doodads or more Exotic weapons, Blackhole Cannons or grab floating Rock or Debris with a Tractor Beam and smash it into them, Rocks and Debris can often do more damage than your own guns, so if you do find some and possibly have a bit of front armour you don't mind getting damaged, shove that garbage in their face for some free damage.

Hooray, you win, well done, now upgrade and win again!
